video.title: React Tutorial: Build an e-commerce site from scratch using React and Netlify
video.description:
Lean step-by-step how to create a full e-commerce store web site using React.js. Also learn how to deploy the site using Netlify. 

Set-up files: https://github.com/john-smilga/setup-filese-react-phone-e-commerce-project

Tutorial from Coding Addict. Check out the Coding Addict YouTube channel: https://www.youtube.com/codingaddict

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://medium.freecodecamp.org

topLevelComment.author: Rakin Moahammad Sifullah
topLevelComment.text:
In react-router-dom ver-6, "Switch" is replaced by routes "Routes". You need to update the import from:  import { Switch, Route } from "react-router-dom";
to: import { Routes ,Route } from 'react-router-dom';

react-dom.development.js:7601 Uncaught DOMException: Failed to execute 'removeChild' on 'Node': The node to be removed is not a child of this node.

replies.author: Aldrich Ang
replies.text:
Okay If anyone has this problem, I solved it.

The problem is the Icon. It cannot be inside a consumer. I guess it is not a valid child. so just change it to a paragraph and not use the icon at all. :(

topLevelComment.author: EMS S
topLevelComment.text: We can create an ecommerce with WordPress so can you tell me what is the advantage to build e-commerce with react? what difference between?

replies.author: Luis Tovar
replies.text: React uses Javascript to make the whole page, this benefits dramatically the performance (storing the data on your device, so you don't ask for it again), when you learn the language you can code faster, also you have "npm" (this comes with Nodejs and it's necessary for React installation), which easily can download code from other users (dependencies); tested and uploaded by the npm's community so you don't have to code what's already made.

topLevelComment.author: Alexander Gorin
topLevelComment.text: Thank you very much for this excellent tutorial. I appreciate it! I used this tutorial as an example for my cleaning stuffs shop: powders, cleaning fluids etc. But in my work I encountered the very big problem: in my shop I've got three different prices for one product (price depends on the volume of cans: half a liter, one liter and five liters). My first approach to solve the task was to create three addToCart methods: addToCart_0_5, addToCart_1 and addToCart_5. In every item in the storeProducts array I made three prices: price_0_5, price_1 and price_5 and in every addToCart methods I refer to the needed price.  But I don't know what to do with the CART in the state of ProductProvider class? Should I do three CARTS: cart_0_5, cart_1 and cart_5? And if I will do this, how can I work with them in the ProductConsumer? May be my thoughts are wrong and there is another solution? If you have any time could you please help me to find the right way in solving my problem: one product - three prices. Thank you very much. Best wishes Alexander Gorin

topLevelComment.author: Adam Coots
topLevelComment.text:
Thank you for this tutorial!!! Great content.
A couple notes of mine to shorten some of the code (in addition to some of the others mentioned like setState) is instead of <React.Fragment></React.Fragment> you can actually use <></>. Also the disabled attribute with the Ternary Operator, instead of disabled={inCart ? true : false} you can simply use disabled={inCart} i believe.

topLevelComment.author: Miguel Gomez
topLevelComment.text: Above all thank you very much for putting the effort in doing this tutorial and the set up files. I have followed along. I can say that React advocates for a minimum  representation of UI state, I believe that if we have a cart , and if there are products in that cart (or not )  , having an extra inCart property inside the object goes against that principle as this could be inferred directly from the cart...

topLevelComment.author: Arctic Monkey
topLevelComment.text:
I don't like the use of font-awesome or bootstrap...
When you are creating something to showcase your skills you should also try to show your creativity. By using font-awesome or bootstrap, your project will be very similar to others and you don't really prove you have good CSS knowledge by using bootstrap classes all over the project.

replies.author: L. F. Febro
replies.text: @Thomas Johnson well said

replies.author: Thomas Johnson
replies.text: He is using CSS within styled components, we should be applauding design systems that have an intended and direct purpose instead of denigrating them;  you can add all the customization you want with a css-in-js library. The reality is most large scale CSS only apps are a mess,  hence why a new CSS pre-processor comes out every day.  Moreover, most painters would consider themselves creative yet most painters also use a frame.

replies.author: lardosian
replies.text: You could always adapt it to your own liking and look at it as a challenge. Would probably add a few more hours to the video and scare people away. Personally i prefer materialize to bootstrap even though its another framework, looks much nicer imo.

replies.author: Arctic Monkey
replies.text:
@Cooper Kernan just giving my opinion. This is still a great react project and the store looks really good.
At least I am adding constructive feedback while you didn't add anything at all except for a troll comment...
